description.narrative:
Rädda Barnen Norge har ansökt om 90 miljoner svenska kronor i stöd i syfte att genomföra programmet "Support for education and successful transitions among vulnerable children in South Sudan" under perioden 2019-2022.
Insatsen syftar till att erbjuda Sydsudanesiska pojkar och flickor tillgång till säker och jämlik utbildning av hög kvalitet. Det kommer att åstadkommas genom: 1) en ökning av antalet funktionella klassrum och utbildningscentrum som kan erbjuda barn och unga fullständig primärutbildning; 2) stärka utbildningens kvalitet genom vidareutbildning av lärare i framför allt inkluderande pedagogik och andra aktiviteter för att skolan ska bli en trygg och säker plats för lärande; 3) åtgärder för att engagera lokala samhällen och inkludera samhällsinstitutioner i styrandet av skolan samt öka lokalsamhällens förståelse för skolan och vikt av utbildning.
I enlighet med Internationella Rädda Barnens organisation ingår Sida avtal med Rädda Barnen Norge som kommer att ha det övergripande finansiella och administrativa ansvaret för insatsen. Rädda Barnen Norge kommer att vidareförmedla 83.3 miljoner svenska kronor till Rädda Barnen Sydsudan, resterande medel behålls av Rädda Barnen Norge och används till kostnader som administration, programutveckling och personalkostnader för personal som inte är direkt involverade i programmet. Rädda Barnen Sydsudan ansvarar för implementeringen av programmet tillsammans med fyra lokala partners: University of Juba, Light for the World, Support for Peace and Education Development Program (SPEDP) och Organization for Peace, Relief and Development (OPRD). Rädda Barnen Sydsudan betalar fakturor för aktiviteter utförda av partners och hanterar vidareförmedling till partners.

Save the Children Norway has applied to Sida for funding of 90 million SEK to carry out the programme "Support for education and successful transitions among vulnerable children in South Sudan" in South Sudan during the period 2019-2022.
The intervention aims at providing continued access to protective, quality and equitable education services for South Sudanese boys and girls. This will be achieved through: 1) an increase in the number of suitable facilities offering children and young people upper-primary and non-formal education services; 2) enhanced quality and inclusiveness of teaching methods and school-based protection mechanisms; and 3) efforts to engage communities and institutions in school governance and quality education delivery.
In accordance with Save the Children International overall organizational structure Sida will sign the agreement with Save the Children Norway that will have the financial oversight and administrative responsibility for the programme. Save the Children Norway will forward 83.3 million SEK to Save the Children South Sudan, the remaining funds will be used for overhead costs such as methodological development, administrative costs and staff costs for people not directly involved in the programme. Save the Children South Sudan will be responsible for implementation of the programme together with four technical and frontline partners: University of Juba, Light for the World, Support for Peace and Education Development Program (SPEDP) och Organization for Peace, Relief and Development (OPRD). Save the Children South Sudan will pay invoices for activities organized by partners and be responsible for forwarding of funds to partners.

The proposed programme aims to provide "increased and continued access to protective, quality and equitable education services through formal and non-formal education streams" for South Sudanese girls and boys in Eastern Equatoria and Jonglei States. The total number of tageted learners are 35 000 in 35 schools and 25 drop-in centres and ALP classes. Teachers, community members and education authorities will also be targeted groups. There are three outcomes: 1) Improved access to and completion of education or skills-based opportunities for children and youth in crisis-affected communities, 2) Enabling learning environments are supported by quality teaching, inclusive methodologies and school-based protection mechanisms, 3) Enhanced community-based and institutional system efficiency in school governance and education. The programme will complement SCI's existing interventions in the targeted locations, of which all has a strong focus on child protection. It means that the programme will be aligned to and include a strong child protection approach. Gender equality, inclusive education for all are other strong approaches. A logical framework has been developed as an annex to the proposal. Some of the stated outputs are: Children are provided with access to education services through upper primary; Children are provided with government approved curriculum and learning supplies; Traning of teachers on primary curriculum, training of teachers on CSG, PFA, PSS and inclusive methodologies; Train Community Mobilisers, run awarness raising activities and events on protection and education, develop and disseminate IEC materials, support role models to promote girls' education; Traon PTAs and SMCs on girls' education, train PTAs and SMCs on monitoring and accountability mechanisms, develop a social audit approach.

description.narrative: Sida received an update on project implementation in April, as well as a proposed COVID-19 response plan. The program activities listed as accomplished were: * gap analysis tool developed and assessment conducted. The purpose of the exercise was to identify targeted school communities, identify and prioritize schools for rehabilitation, enrollment, teacher recruitment. * planning/preparation for base-line survey, May is the tentative timeline. * engagement with MoGEI on inclusive education policy i.e initial meetings with relevant Director General. MoGEI has proposed to convene a technical committee with different sector actors to move this process forward. * coordination with partners i.e. frontline, technical to ensure planning is harmonized, and workplans are agreed. Activities accomplished related to HR, procurement and awards are: * procurement process for teaching and learning materials is on-going. * recruitment process is complete, all field based staff are on board with exception of construction supervisor. * partnership agreements signed with frontline partners; pre-award letter has been issued to technical partner (for inclusion)
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
